[Charles Petit to Nathanael Greene
November 2, 1781
[RvW Box 2 Folder 58; MSS. – A.L.S.]]

Philadelphia 2d. Novem.r 1781
Dear Sir,
It was not till some days after Major Pierce's arrival in
this town that I received your fav.r of the 17th. of Sept.r owing,
as he afterwards told me, to its being packed up with his eastern
letters; and as I had not had the pleasure to be acquainted with
him before, I began to apprehend I should lose the opportunity
of getting that information about you which a tete a tete only
can give.  After receiving your letter, however, I sought and
obtained an acquaintance with the Major, and it has been a
pleasing one -  I can only regret that circumstances have not
permitted him to spend so much time with my family as I 
wished, as well on account of his own merit, as from the regard
you express for him.
I congratulate you most sincerely on your series of
successes amidst the series of complicated difficulties you have
had to encounter, and particularly in the arduous affair at Eutaw.
I leave it to your less firmly attacked friends, and to the world
at large to sound your praises and speak of your merit and
that of the band of Heroes it has been your good fortune to
command: they do it I assure you not unsparingly, and I feel
myself so much interested in it, that on many occasions I seem
to feel myself as your representative in receiving the incence [sic]
and in such cases the calls of modesty oblige me to say no more
than that to shew [sic] that I receive it with grateful complacence. Were there
any doubtful points, or any clouds or shades arising which
would obscure the brilliancy of your conduct, it would become
your friends to remove them; but nothing of the sort appears,
and I may say with a truth that fills me with satisfaction
that no campaign or series of actions during the war has obtained 
more universal approbation [and] applause than those in the Carolinas
during the last twelve months – May your Laurels never 
fade!
Major Pearce is kind enough to take charge of 7 shirts
and as many stocks for you. Major Burnet undertook to
send you a hat with some other articles he had in charge
to forward to you. What he has done respecting them I am
not informed, not having heard from him since Major Pierce's 
arrival
[End Page 1]
arrival. I fear his health has failed him, or that some other
cause not known when he went from here, detains him. I have
neither seen nor heard from him since Major Pierce's arrival.
He left in my hands some bills of Exch.g – at first he desired me
to sell a few to raise a little ready money for Capt. Swan [and] some other
purposes; afterwards he desired me to sell more. I went on till
I had sold upwards of 20,000 dollars. Majr. Burnet, for certain reasons,
thought it best not to communicate to the Treasury that he had these
bills; but the sale brought it to the knowledge of the Financier
who has spoke to me on the subject [and] desired me to sell no more.
I did not inform him of the quantity, but left him to suppose it
was about 20,000 Dollars. - The money is yet chiefly unappropriated.
They sold from 5/. to 5/3 the dollar. If the money is to be turned over
to the Treasury, which may be the case if they undertake to furnish
the supplies Major Burnet is in pursuit of, I shall try hard to get
payment out of it for our Iron contract [and] for some contingent
expences [sic] of Office I have been obliged to make advances for since
my supplies of cash failed. This, however must be as circumstances
will admit.
I have heard some rumours [sic] that Mrs. Greene is on
the way hither. From my own opinion, strongly corroborated
by your friends from the Southward, [and] those in this Town, we shall
endeavour [sic] to convince her that it is best to proceed no farther. We shall
be happy in her company here as long as we can make this Town
agreeable to her, and I have plenty of house-room to spare her.
If, however she should determine to proceed, we will endeavour to
accomodate [sic] her in it. In either case I will furnish her with what 
money she shall choose to take.  While you are kept out of
Charleston, Carolina must be an inconvenient residence for her
without taking into consideration the unavoidable difficulties and
inconveniences of this Journey, which are dreadful in idea, [and] must
be worse in practice to a lady. If you should crown your career
of success by the possession of Charleston, you may, like Alexander,
mourn that you have nothing more to conquer – and in that case
you will, of course as I take it, come to the northward.
I am obliged to write this in haste. Having supposed that I
had the week before me to write to you I put off the business; but
this morning Major Pierce informs me he is to go off at one or
two o'clock [and] the hour is at hand.
I will
[End Page 2]
I will however put in a word or two on our concerns.
I have before informed you that I had bargained away
the 1/8th of the Ship Revolution, the principal part of the paymt.
was in meadow lots – the residue not yet rec.d – The ship
however was taken a few days after, so that what we got was 
so much saved.
The ship Congress sent in a Brig, which produced the
Owners little more than [British pounds]2000. After that she put in to Cape
Francois [and] contracted a debt of upwards of [British pounds]2000. From whence
she went on a cruize intending to send in Prizes to pay the
debt. Off of Charleston she fell in with the Savage Sloop of
war [a ship near her own size, mounting 16 sixes [and] four
fours] which she took after an obstinate engagement which
obliged her to proceed homewards. On the way the prize
was retaken by the Solebay Frigate [and] returned to Charleston, so
that the Congress returned emptyhanded [and] a good deal mauled.
At a meeting of the Owners it was carried by a large ma-
jority that privateering was become ineligible [and] that the
ship should go on a Voyage. This debt in the W. Indies must
be paid [and] no way could be found but by sending the ship to
do it – She is now loaded [and] will sail in a few days for the 
Havanna – from thence she is to proceed to Amsterdam [and] re
turn with such property as she creates for the Owners [and] a
Freight of dry goods.   In the mean time, however, the
meadow lots being an useless kind of property to us, [and] wanting
much expence to put them in order, I bartered them away
for 1/32d of the Ship Congress; which I intended should be on
our comp.y account. Mr. Cox declines taking a farther int.r
in the ship, though he would not consent to sell our original 
1/16th – I therefore requested him to elect for you as to the new
purchase – he declined it. We therefore decided the matter
by lot, which gave you this farther concern – that is instead
of 1/3d. of a sixteenth, you now own 1/3d. of 3/32ds. It shall
however be in your option to take your proportion of
this additional 1/32d. or not – you will please to communicate
yr. determination. It cost [British pounds]500 – that is valuing the ship
at a [British pounds]16000, subject to the debt abroad [and] the new outfit – She
carries about 1900 bar.s of Flour [and] draws a freight of one half
to the Hav.a from thence to Europe from 1/4 to 1/2 of the
sugars
[End Page 3]
as may happen; [and] from Amsterdam hither about 10 pCent in
dry goods if the war should continue – She equals our expectations
in point of sailing, that is, beats everything; but carries too little for
her size [and] force. Mr. Cox at present declines making any insur.e
on the orig.l 1/16. but I have thought of making some on the addit.l
32d. especially if it rests all on me – Will you have any? The prin[cipal]
will be about 40 pCt. round.
The Iron Works have finished their blast. The prospect of
peace makes me doubtful whether to prepare for another at a
war expence, which is at least 50 pCt. more than that of peace.
The forge is in forwardness [and] will be ready to work in 2 months or
less.  I find the business so heavy [and] requiring so much attention
[and] skill [on which the profits entirely depend] [and] the difficulties so
great of getting proper hands [and] seeing that every thing draws righ[t]
that I am under strong temptations to sell out if it can be done.
If I could get an owner interested who understood it [and] would ma[ke]
it his business I would gladly keep a concern; but I am not su[f]
ficiently skilled in it myself to make it either your interest or
mine to bestow the trouble it requires to keep it going extensive[ly]
Yet it is an estate I have an attachment to, [and] my mind recoils a[t] 
the serious thought of parting with it.
I fear being too late with my letter [and] therefore must
cut it short – Mr. Reed writes to you himself [and] therefore
I can with the more ease avoid political subjects.
Believe me with firm affection
Dr Sir
Your most obt. Servt. [obedient Servant]
C. [Charles] Pettit				
[Endorsed on the right margin:]  From Col.o [Colonel] Pettit
Novr. [November] 2d 1781
[End Page 4]
